subject: CLASSPATH (Re: [junit] NoClassDefFoundError)
msgSnippet: Ladies and Gentlemen... Setting the environment CLASSPATH to run simple Java applications is just another way to use global data. The environment CLASSPATH is
messageBody:
Ladies and Gentlemen...

Setting the environment CLASSPATH to run simple Java applications is just another way to use global data. The environment CLASSPATH is global data and should be avoided.

May I recommend specifying the CLASSPATH you need each time you run a Java application without stuffing extra crap into your environment. This way you know exactly what's on the CLASSPATH each time you run the application.

Take care.

>So said Jason Rogers on 2003-07-04 --------------------
>On Fri, 04 Jul 2003 19:30:28 -0000, "sutantoc74" <sutantoc74@...>
>said:
>> Hi All,
>>
>> I am new with JUnit. I have two test files and one test suite file,
>> unfortunately when I try to run the testrunner from any directory, I
>> always get a NoClassDefFoundError.
>> [snip]
>> Can somebody let me know what's wrong? Thanks
>
>Charles,
>
>This is a typical Java classpath issue. What class name is in the stack
>trace? Make sure that class in on your classpath. From a commandline
>you can type one of the following to see what your classpath is set to...
>
> Unix: echo $CLASSPATH
> Windows: echo %CLASSPATH%
>
>--
>=jason
>[:question | ^One]
